prefix: Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in mathematics would.
problem_prompt: Approach the following question the way someone with a PhD in mathematics would. Let $a\equiv (3^{-1}+5^{-1}+7^{-1})^{-1}\pmod{11}$. What is the remainder when $a$ is divided by $11$?
solution:
One way to do this is to find each inverse explicitly: \begin{align*}
(3^{-1}+5^{-1}+7^{-1})^{-1} &\equiv (4+9+8)^{-1} \pmod{11} \\
&\equiv 21^{-1} \pmod{11} \\
&\equiv 10^{-1} \pmod{11} \\
&\equiv \boxed{10}\pmod{11}.
\end{align*} Another way to do this is through manipulation: \begin{align*}
& (3^{-1}+5^{-1}+7^{-1})^{-1}\\
\equiv~ & (3\cdot 5\cdot 7)(3\cdot 5\cdot 7)^{-1}(3^{-1}+5^{-1}+7^{-1})^{-1}\\
\equiv~ & (3\cdot 5\cdot 7)(3\cdot 5+5\cdot 7+ 7\cdot 3)^{-1}\\
\equiv~ & 6\cdot(15+35+21)^{-1}\\
\equiv~ & 6\cdot 5^{-1}\\
\equiv~ & 6\cdot 9\\
\equiv~ & \boxed{10} \pmod{11}
\end{align*}
gpt_response:
To find the value of $a$, we first need to calculate the inverses of $3$, $5$, and $7$ modulo $11$. The inverses of $3$, $5$, and $7$ modulo $11$ are $4$, $9$, and $8$ respectively, since $3\cdot 4\equiv 1\pmod{11}$, $5\cdot 9\equiv 1\pmod{11}$, and $7\cdot 8\equiv 1\pmod{11}$.

Therefore, $a\equiv (4+9+8)^{-1}\pmod{11}$. Computing the sum inside the parentheses first, we get $4+9+8=21$, so $a\equiv 21^{-1}\pmod{11}$.

Now we need to find the inverse of $21$ modulo $11$. Since $21\equiv 10\pmod{11}$, we have $a\equiv 10^{-1}\pmod{11}$.

We need to find the multiplicative inverse of $10$ modulo $11$. This is $10$ itself because $10\cdot 10\equiv 1\pmod{11}$.

Therefore, $a\equiv 10\pmod{11}$. The remainder when $a$ is divided by $11$ is $10$.

Now we need to find the inverse of $21$ modulo $11$. Since $21\equiv 10\pmod{11}$, we have $a\equiv 10^{-1}\pmod{11}$.

We need to find the multiplicative inverse of $10$ modulo $11$. This is $10$ itself because $10\cdot 10\equiv 1\pmod{11}$.
